title: African Potash signs fertiliser supply deal in Africa
text:
African Potash signs fertiliser supply deal in Africa 30 September 2015 Print Email 
African exploration company African Potash has signed deals to supply fertiliser in Zambia and Congo. 
The company has signed a fertiliser supply agreement (FFSA) with South Africa-based Cudolog, and African co-operative group Comesa for the supply of fertiliser in Congo. 
Under the agreement, Cudolog will supply 50,000t of fertiliser, including 25,000t of NPKD compound, and 25,000t of UREA. 
Cudolog will deliver the fertiliser to chosen port destinations. Currently, the company is organising continental transport. "We now pleased to have concluded this agreement for fertiliser supply, which provides us with access to the required quantity and quality of fertilisers." 
The contract was signed during the East and Southern Africa Fertiliser Trade Platform (ESAF) annual conference and fertiliser expo held in Lusaka, Zambia. 
Following the first MOU announced last August, the FFSA is considered to be a significant development towards implementing African Potash's strategy of becoming a vertically integrated African-focused fertiliser business. 
African Potash executive chairman Chris Cleverly said: "Having established a sale price of $500 per metric tonne in respect of the 50,000 metric tonnes of fertiliser product to be supplied in connection with our first trading MOU. 
"We are now pleased to have concluded this agreement for fertiliser supply, which provides us with access to the required quantity and quality of fertilisers, at competitive pricing structures. 
"We are continuing to establish relationships and work towards concluding agreements to complete the full trading chain and look forward to providing further updates on these developments in due course." 
The company has announced that is in negotiating to establish a trade finance facility of around $50m to fund its trading operations. 
African Potash has also signed a deal with a local Congolese distributor to supply 150,000t of fertiliser to Congo. 
The supply will be done under the the COMESA Trading MOU, under which the company, along with Mask Africa Crowd Farm Fund, agreed to supply and deliver at least 500,000t of fertiliser during the first three years. 
Cleverly said: "No region of the world has been able to expand agricultural growth rates, and thus tackle hunger, without increasing fertiliser use. 
"Despite economic growth rates of 8.9% in 2014, according to World Bank figures the Democratic Republic of Congo currently uses only 1kg of fertiliser per hectare of arable land, whereas India uses 16kg per hectare, and the United Kingdom uses 234kg per hectare." Follow Us:
